Designating National Parks can greatly enhance [ICON_Tourism] Tourism and [ICON_Amenities] Amenities. National Parks are designated by Naturalist units, which may be purchased in your city with [ICON_Faith] Faith after researching the Conservation civic.
National Parks can be built on a cluster of any four tiles that meet the following requirements:

1. The tiles must be natural wonders, mountains, or a tile with an Appeal of Charming or better.[NEWLINE]2. All four of the tiles must be owned by the same city.[NEWLINE]3. The tiles must be contiguous and form a diamond shape.[NEWLINE]4. No tile can have an improvement or district.

You can select a Naturalist to reveal any valid locations on the map. Sending the Naturalist to any highlighted tile will reveal the Designate National Park action button. Clicking on this button designates the National Park and consumes the Naturalist.

A National Park's [ICON_Tourism] Tourism output is equal to the total Appeal of all the tiles included in the park. Additionally, the city that owns the park receives 2 [ICON_Amenities] Amenities, and the four closest cities in your civilization receive 1 [ICON_Amenities] Amenity.
Victory and Defeat
Introduction

There are multiple ways to win and lose a game in Civilization VI. It's important to keep an eye on your opponents' progress toward victory as you advance your own civilization. There's nothing quite as annoying as to be on the verge of capturing your last surviving enemy's final city, only to watch helplessly as he or she completes her Mars colony and wins an upset Science Victory.
Domination Victory

If you are the last player in possession of your own original [ICON_Capital] Capital, you win. So if you capture all other civilizations' [ICON_Capital] Capitals and hang onto your own, you've achieved victory. However, this can be tricky. Suppose you're in a five-player game and you capture three of your opponents' original [ICON_Capital] Capitals, but the fifth player sneaks in and captures your [ICON_Capital] Capital while you're not paying attention – then he would win immediately. In other words, it doesn't matter who captures what: it's the last player holding onto his original [ICON_Capital] Capital who gets the victory.

If you've lost your original [ICON_Capital] Capital, but still possess other cities, you can still win another type of victory: Culture, Science, Score, or Religious. However, you cannot win a Domination Victory until and unless you recapture your own original [ICON_Capital] Capital.
Science Victory

The Science Victory is achieved by the first player to establish a colony on the planet Mars. Once the Space Race is underway, and someone has launched their first satellite, all players will know who is attempting this victory. Players receive bonuses for reaching each milestone along the way to victory. The following steps must be completed in order:
Launch a Satellite into Space:

Reminiscent of Sputnik in 1957, you may build a satellite to launch into space after researching Rocketry and building a Spaceport. After completing the Earth Satellite project, your satellite will be launched and you will be awarded visibility of the entire map.
Land a Human on the Moon:

Just like the Apollo 11 mission in 1969, you will send a human to the moon. This is unlocked after researching the technology Satellites, and can be built in any city with a Spaceport. Choose to produce the Moon Landing project to begin this mission. After the rocket has been launched, you will immediately be rewarded a lump sum of [ICON_Culture] Culture.
Establish a Colony on Mars:

Science fiction for now, perhaps – but now you can be the first to send your people to Mars. After researching Robotics, Nuclear Fission, and Nanotechnology, you may build the Reactor, Habitation, and Hydroponics module projects in any city with a Spaceport. Note that more than one Spaceport means parallel production!
Once every piece is launched, you have won the game.
Culture Victory

If you aim to be the cultural epicenter of the world, this is the victory for you. The first civilization to possess a total number of [ICON_Tourism] Visiting Tourists that exceeds the [ICON_Tourism] Domestic Tourists of each other civilization in the game wins the Culture Victory.

[ICON_Tourism] Tourism is generated by [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes, shared (or conflicting) late game Governments, open borders, Great Works housed in your civilization, [ICON_GreatWork_Relic] Relics housed in your civilization, Holy Sites, National Parks, [ICON_GreatWork_Artifact] Artifacts, and wonders.
Religious Victory

In order to obtain a Religious Victory, you must make your Religion the predominant Religion for every other major civilization in the game. This means not every one of a civilization's cities must follow your Religion, just the majority.
While your Religion will spread passively simply by settling near other players, it is your Missionaries and Apostles who offer the best chance at victory.
Score Victory

In many games, one of the players will win the game by achieving one of the possible victories. However, if no one achieves one of these victories by the year 2050 (or a player-set turn), the winner is determined by the surviving civilization's "score." Points for your score are earned from number of civics, number of population, number of cities, number of technologies, number of "future technologies", number of wonders, military accomplishments, number of [ICON_GreatPerson] Great People, and number of Beliefs.
